conclusion: Analyze the v-t graph to determine collision time relative to 20 seconds.
Graph shows velocity of two cars over time with points A and B for Car A and Car B.
Point A is above Point B initially, indicating Car A has a higher initial velocity.
Collision occurs when cars are at the same position, depending on relative velocities and initial positions.
Intersection of lines indicates equal velocities, not necessarily collision.
Collision occurs when distance between cars becomes zero, found by integrating relative velocity.
Intersection of lines occurs around t = 25 seconds, velocities approximately 15 m/s.
Position found by integrating velocity over time; Car A starts behind Car B.
Deceleration rates: Car A = 0.4 m/s², Car B = 0.6 m/s².
Car A will catch up to Car B if its deceleration is insufficient to prevent closing the distance.
Intersection at t = 25 s is critical; Car A might overtake Car B shortly after.
Collision occurs after 20 seconds as intersection and critical velocity alignment happen at t = 25 s.
The two cars collide after 20 seconds of braking.
